results.title: Where's Pete?
results.creator_credit: Jim Purdy, John Spotton, Michael Scott and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: Addresses the response of a seven-year-old to the death of his teenage brother. Chad, who hopes his brother, Pete, will coach the grade two hockey team, arrives home from school to discover that Pete has died in a car accident. The film details the experiences and feelings of Chad and his parents during the first few weeks of bereavement. Throughout, Chad has flashbacks of the good times he had with his brother.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Jim Purdy, John Spotton, Michael Scott and National Film Board of Canada

results.title: When your time is your own
results.creator_credit: Ernest Reid and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: This film considers the question of how to use the increasing amount of leisure time that people now have - and will have even more of through modern technology. It suggests the pleasures of creative pursuits such as pottery, painting, dancing and amateur theatre, and shows how the enthusiasm of a few who organise group activities can draw many others to develop latent talents.

results.title: When you're in love
results.brief_description: A light romantic musical comedy featuring Cary Grant in the role of Jimmy Hudson, an artist who finds himself involved in a bizarre plot with an Australian opera star by the name of Louise Fuller (played by American born Grace Moore). Louise Fuller is desperate to perform in America but cannot obtain a visa, and the only other way she can enter America is if she is married. On meeting the handsome artist, Louise cons him into a marriage of convenience offering him the sum of $2,000 for his part in the scheme. And so begins a most unlikely liaison, a mis-matched couple who continually battle it out with each other until finally love steps in. The highlight among the many songs featured in the film is “Minnie the Moocher”, a sultry, sexy song wonderfully performed by Grace Moore, an opera singer in real life. Story based on an idea by Ethel Hill and Cedric Worth with original music by Jerome Kern. Cast also includes Aline MacMachon, Henry Stephenson, Thomas Mitchell, Catharine Doucet.

results.title: When will they realise we're living in the 20th century?
results.brief_description: John Cleese plays the roles of both the Shop Steward and the Production Director, each of whom tells his side of the story to the audience regarding a production dispute. As the film proceeds, the mistaken assumptions, actions and attitudes that precipitated the dispute are revealed. Suitable for upper secondary and tertiary levels.

results.title: When will the day break? = Wen tian he shi ming = 問天何時明
results.creator_credit: Qin Wei, Yue Yu, Ma Erlu, Yabiao Wang and Beijing Film Studio
results.brief_description:
This film talks about China during the time in which the Wannan Incident (also known as the New Fourth Army Incident) occurred in the 1940s. This incident happened during the Second Sino-Japanese War; at the time when the Chinese Civil War was (in theory) withheld and the Communists and Nationalists joined forces to fight against the Japanese. The Wannan Incident was created by the hands of the Nationalist party leader Jiang Kai-Shek and the incident spurred indignation all over China. While confronting the hype of anti-Japanese campaigns all over the country, Jiang Kai-Shek tries to suppress the Chinese Communists Party (CCP) and scholars with violence. Guo Moruo, a scholar and a fugitive who rebelled against Jiang’s political ideologies returns to China to participate in the fight against the invasion of Japanese.

Upon Guo’s return to China, he is angered by the corruption of the Nationalist Party’s Government rules and the disastrous state of the country. His rage inspired him to create a historical theatre piece known as “Qu Yuan”. After Guo completed his creative piece, Zhou En the director of the Eighth Route Army subscriptions office, enthusiastically encourages and supports Guo’s production; emphasizing that revolution literary scholars like Guo can use their script writing talent as a weapon to attack their enemies.

“Qu Yuan” finally proceeds on stage; and the show was a success across Chong Qing—spreading its fame throughout the whole of China. Subsequently, the fame of such a play which embedded controversial ideologies against the Nationalists ideals infuriated Jiang. Jiang ordered Zhou En to force Guo to apologise and admit that they were wrong to produce such a play, but Zhou did not do as he was told. Failing to force Guo, his supporters and the production to stop, Zhang Du, the advertising director of the Literary Cultural Conference tries to attack Guo’s moves by asking difficult questions. A reporter asks whether Guo is a supporter of the Communist Party, Guo answers “Are all Buddhists monks in this world?” Guo replies all questions with ease and at ease, effectively using language, humour, wisdom and research to ‘dodge bullets’ fired at him by troublemakers at the conference.

Guo attempts to break through the obstacles set for him and Chong Qing so that he can continue to preach his wisdom and political visions to other parts of China by moving Northward with his theatre production. On the day of the Dragon Boat Festival, the theatre group set sail on a big ship, but police speedboats unexpectedly appear, making an attempt to stop them from leaving. At once, theatre group troupes waved a flag vigorously in the air and dragon boats sailing next to their ship immediately turn their boats to face the police speedboats head-on. As all dragon boats united to interfere with the police chase, it was an obvious picture that epitomize the strength of people power; the dragon boats are confronting police forces, and viewers can read that they are also working for what they believe is right—confronting corruption, injustice and power of the Nationalist Party. While the dragon boats break the police chase, the theatre group is able to be on their way. In the final scenes, Guo Moruo raises both hands into the heavens, showing his deep gratitude towards his Chinese comrades.
(Pearl Lau, 2013).
results.title_for_label: When will the day break? = Wen tian he shi ming = 問天何時明

results.title: When will people help?
results.brief_description: Based on the murder of a young woman in New York where 38 neighbours refused to intervene. Records experiments in social psychology showing factors that lead to bystander apathy.

results.title: When we were kings [DVD]
results.creator_credit: Taylor Hackford, Leon Gast, David Sonenberg and DAS Films
results.brief_description: The heavyweight title fight between Muhammad Ali and George Foreman in Kinshasa (Zaire) on 30 October 1974 - `The Rumble in the Jungle’ - is enshrined as one of the great sports events of the century. It was also a cultural and political happening. Utilizing original footage of the fight, the film is on one level a lost documentary revealing never-before-seen images of the Fight of the Century between a then relatively unpopular, but fearsome, boxer named George Foreman and his nearly mythical antagonist, the incomparable Muhammad Ali. Filmmakers Gast and Hackford also construct a riveting story of the drama and significance of an event which signified the beginning of a new age of black culture and identity. Complete with performances by B.B. King, James Brown, and Miriam Makeba, marked by the launching of the career of notorious promoter Don King, and overshadowed by the ominous presence of Zaire’s President Mobutu, this is a discourse on what it meant to be black in America in that tumultuous time. Not only does the film deal with issues of segregation and integration and the emergence of black pride and black consciousness, but most critically, it describes the return to Africa of black American visitors. At the centre of the film is Ali, who, both as athlete and entertainer, persona and man, is a compelling figure, deeply committed to issues of racial, religious and political justice. The film also features insights and commentary from Norman Mailer, George Plimpton, and Spike Lee.

results.title: When war came to Australia
results.creator_credit: Bill Hosking, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: A recent visit to Darwin with his son reminded Bill Hosking of the time that war came to Australia. As one of the men who defended Darwin during that time, he was instructed to keep the details of the attack secret. In 1942, Bill Hosking joined up and was shipped up to train in the Northern Territory. It was during this time that the air raids on Darwin took place. Bill shares his experiences because he believes that not many people today know the story of how Australia came under attack.

results.title: When the state kills
results.creator_credit: Stephen Trombley, Bruce Eadie and Channel Four Television Corporation
results.brief_description: This tape discusses the history of state execution across countries such as the United States, United Kingdom, Nigeria, France, Afghanistan, China, the Phillipines and Saudi Arabia. Interviews are conducted with historians, families of those executed, legal personnel and executioners. Issues covered include; the disproportion of poorer people and non-whites on death row in America, the transformation from hanging processions to a search for more humane ways to end death and distance executioners from their actions, a case study of David Lawson who died by lethal injection, the abolition and reinstatement of the death penalty in America, and the case of capital punishment in Trinidad. This documentary contains graphic scenes of execution methods including the guillotine, firing squad and hanging. Suitable for upper secondary level.
